t: Proverbs 23
On Life and Conduct
When*pn you sit down to dine with a ruler, Consider*ln carefully what is before you,
And*ln put a knife to your throat If*ln you are a man of great*i appetite.
Do*ln not desire his delicacies, For*ln it is deceptive food.
Do*ln not weary yourself to gain wealth, Cease*ln from your consideration of*i it.*i
When*ln you set your eyes on it, it is gone. For*ln wealth*i certainly makes itself wings Like*ln an eagle that flies toward*i the heavens.
Do*ln not eat the bread of a selfish man, Or*ln desire his delicacies;
For*ln as he thinks within himself, so he is. He*ln says to you, “Eat and drink!” But*ln his heart is not with you.
You*ln will vomit up the morsel you have eaten, And*ln waste your compliments.
Do*ln not speak in the hearing of a fool, For*ln he will despise the wisdom of your words.
Do*ln not move the ancient boundary Or*ln go into the fields of the fatherless,
For*ln their Redeemer is strong; He*ln will plead their case against you.
Apply*ln your heart to discipline And*ln your ears to words of knowledge.
Do*ln not hold back discipline from the child, Although*ln you strike him with the rod, he will not die.
You*ln shall strike him with the rod And*ln rescue his soul from Sheol.
My*ln son, if your heart is wise, My*ln own heart also will be glad;
And*ln my inmost being will rejoice When*ln your lips speak what is right.
Do*ln not let your heart envy sinners, But*ln live*i in the fear of the Lord*s always.
Surely*ln there is a future, And*ln your hope will not be cut off.
Listen,*ln my son, and be wise, And*ln direct your heart in the way.
Do*ln not be with heavy drinkers of wine, Or*iln with gluttonous eaters of meat;
For*ln the heavy drinker and the glutton will come to poverty, And*ln drowsiness will clothe one*i with rags.
Listen*ln to your father who begot you, And*ln do not despise your mother when she is old.
Buy*ln truth, and do not sell it,*i Get*iln wisdom and instruction and understanding.
The*ln father of the righteous will greatly rejoice, And*ln he who sires a wise son will be glad in him.
Let*ln your father and your mother be glad, And*ln let her rejoice who gave birth to you.
Give*ln me your heart, my son, And*ln let your eyes delight in my ways.
For*ln a harlot is a deep pit And*ln an adulterous woman is a narrow well.
Surely*ln she lurks as a robber, And*ln increases the faithless among men.
Who*ln has woe? Who has sorrow? Who*ln has contentions? Who has complaining? Who*ln has wounds without cause? Who*ln has redness of eyes?
Those*ln who linger long over wine, Those*ln who go to taste mixed wine.
Do*ln not look on the wine when it is red, When*ln it sparkles in the cup, When*ln it goes down smoothly;
At*ln the last it bites like a serpent And*ln stings like a viper.
Your*ln eyes will see strange things And*ln your mind will utter perverse things.
And*ln you will be like one who lies down in the middle of the sea, Or*ln like one who lies down on the top of a mast.
“They*ln struck me, but*i I did not become ill; They*ln beat me, but*i I did not know it.*i When*ln shall I awake? I*ln will seek another drink.”
